tossups.question: While speaking to reporters, Antonio Cassano was kicked in the head by this man. Vandals sawed the leg and nose off of a bronze statue of this man, which stood for only 3 months before being removed for preservation. On an episode of Ellen, this man surprised the Thai junior soccer team that had been rescued from Tham Luang (“TOM lu-wong”) cave. This footballer’s MLS debut was in El Tráfico as a substitute, where he scored a (*) 45-yard goal as part of a 3-goal comeback. During a 2013 friendly with England, this man scored 4 goals, finishing with a 35-yard bicycle kick often considered one of the greatest goals of all time. For 10 points, name this Bosniak Swedish striker who refers to himself in the third person.

For 10 points, name this Bosniak Swedish striker who refers to himself in the third person.

tossups.question: These people made an annual offering to the sun goddess Arinna in their one-time capital of Tarhuntassa. A text discovered at Bogazkale (“bo-az-KAH-lay”) was written by Kikkuli, a master horse trainer of these people, and provides noted evidence of loanwords from Indo-Aryan languages. The Hayasa and Kaskas were defeated by these people, which allowed these people to re-establish their capital under (*) Suppiluliuma I (“sup-pi-lul-li-YOO-ma the first”). Clay tablets unearthed in 1906 contain these people’s version of the Silver Treaty, written in cuneiform, while their [emphasize] opponents’ version was found in a temple of Ramses II (“the second”). For 10 points, name these ancient people who fought the Egyptians under their king Mutawalli II at the battle of Kadesh.

For 10 points, name these ancient people who fought the Egyptians under their king Mutawalli II at the battle of Kadesh.

tossups.question: The musician Reginal Smith Brindle composed settings of the poems of Garcia Lorca for this instrument. J.S. Bach composed an E minor piece titled Bourrée for this instrument. It’s not a violin, but Lee Krasner owned the extremely-rare Rawlins one of these instruments produced by Antonio Stradivari. A strict teacher of this instrument criticised the unorthodox style that John Williams used when playing this instrument with the group Sky. The iconic (*) Nokia theme was taken from Gran Vals, a composition for this instrument by Francisco Tárrega. Joaquín (“wa-KEEN”) Rodrigo composed the Concierto de Aranjuez (“con-see-AIR-to day a-RAHN-ways”) for this instrument. Andrés Segovia and Julian Bream were virtuosos of this instrument. For 10 points, name this instrument which typically has six strings and is related to the lute.
tossups.question_sanitized: The musician Reginal Smith Brindle composed settings of the poems of Garcia Lorca for this instrument. J.S. The iconic (*) Nokia theme was taken from Gran Vals, a composition for this instrument by Francisco Tárrega. Joaquín (“wa-KEEN”) Rodrigo composed the Concierto de Aranjuez (“con-see-AIR-to day a-RAHN-ways”) for this instrument. Andrés Segovia and Julian Bream were virtuosos of this instrument. For 10 points, name this instrument which typically has six strings and is related to the lute.

tossups.question: In 2021, this country's government demoed a device that could slow Internet connections to certain websites. Bellingcat controversially pays for leaked databases on a thriving illicit data network in this country, which was the target of accusation in the first Bellingcat report. A fight broke out during a Bosnia-Ukraine World Cup qualifier after this country's flag was displayed upside down and confused for a similar flag. Dick (*) Pound led a 2015 investigation into conduct by an agency in this country. This country is home to the Internet Research Agency, a massive state-linked troll farm. For 10 points, name this country that was banned from competing in international sports for two years in 2019 for their massive doping program.

tossups.question: This play’s author told Claude Bonnefoy that he considered ending it by firing at the audience with machine guns. Footnotes in the script of this play frequently contrast it with Nicolas Bataille’s (“nee-ko-lah ba-TIE’s”) production of it. After the lights shut off at the end of this play, the characters all shout “it’s not that way, it’s over here!” before the play starts over with the characters swapped. The Smiths discuss the death of Bobby Watson in this play, set on an (*) English evening in an English middle-class interior after the clock strikes 17 English strokes. The title character of this play is only mentioned in passing by the Fire Chief. For 10 points, name this seminal work in the Theatre of the Absurd, an “anti-play” by Eugène Ionesco (“uh-JEN yo-NESS-ko”).
tossups.answer: The Bald Soprano [or La Cantatrice chauve; accept The Bald Prima Donna]

tossups.answer_sanitized: The Bald Soprano [or La Cantatrice chauve; accept The Bald Prima Donna]

tossups.question: Trimethoprim ("tri-METH-o-prim") can fail to kill bacteria grown without both this molecule and methionine, because its synthesis is dependent on tetrahydrofolate. A trimethylated ("tri-METH-eel-ated") version of this molecule allows sugar beets to retain water and is the classic betaine ("BEET-ane"). By coincidence, this amino acid shares its name with the genus for soybeans because both are slightly sweet. This amino acid is produced by dehydroxymethylating ("de-hy-DROXY-meth-eel-ating") serine. Unmodified residues of this amino acid comprise one-third of collagen’s triple helix, but both it and proline are more common in loops because they (*) break alpha helices. This amino acid’s Ramachandran plot is uniquely symmetric because it is the only achiral (“ay-KYE-ral”) one. For 10 points, name this amino acid with only a hydrogen atom as a side chain with symbol “G”.
tossups.answer: glycine [or Gly; accept Glycine max; prompt on G before mentioned]

tossups.answer_sanitized: glycine [or Gly; accept Glycine max; prompt on G before mentioned]

The website Niconico (“neeko-neeko”) pioneered a form of these things known as danmaku, named for resembling a bullet curtain. tossups.question: In the work Le Mondain ("luh MON-dan"), this thinker proposed that worldly pleasure-seeking actually leads to virtue. A collaborator of this thinker secretly submitted an essay on the nature of fire to compete with his essay, but he advocated for it to be published anyway. This thinker propounded Newtonianism and made an early empirical argument for smallpox inoculation in his Letters on the English, written after his (*) exile to London. This thinker lived and collaborated with Emilie du Châtelet (“shot-lay”), who protected him from royal sanction. This thinker had a long rivalry with Jean-Jacques Rousseau, and caricatured another thinker he disliked as saying that we are in "the best of all possible worlds." For 10 points, which Enlightenment philosopher satirized Gottfried Leibniz as Dr. Pangloss in his novel Cqndide?

tossups.question: During the manufacture of this good in German cities like Lüneburg and Halle (“HALL-la”), blood and beer were added to this good to purify it. Malangis ("muh-LAHN-geez") manufactured this good in Orissa before a British monopoly took it over. A Roman road from Castrum Truentinum was named for this good, and a Latin word for a lustful man derived from this good. This was the primary good traded to the city of (*) Djenne ("jen-AY"). Along with gold, this was one of the primary goods traded across the Sahara. To protest a tax on this good, Mahatma Gandhi led a march to Dandi. For 10 points, name this good that was prized for its ability to preserve meat.

Henry Gunther died in this year, and the sailor-led Kiel Mutiny occurred in this year. The first notable usage of the Wagon of Compiègne (“kom-PYEN”) occurred during this year. tossups.question: Actor Michael C. Hall, Peter Yanowitz, and Matt Katz-Bohen are members of a musical trio titled [this word] Goes to the Butterfly Museum. A Stock, Aitken, and Waterman musician with this one word name had her only major hit with 1985’s “Say I’m Your Number One”. tossups.question: Two divergent variants of this art form named “bird” and “worm” emerged in response to the introduction of bronze ware in China. Ottoman Turks developed a dense, space-filling variant of this art form known as diwani, as well as the open, expressive thuluth form. Emperor Taizong is purportedly buried with a work in this art form that was inspired by the Orchid Pavilion; that work was the magnum opus of Wang Xizhi (“SHI-cherr”). Rotundas and (*) ligatures frequently appear in a German variant of this art form called Fraktur (“frock-tour”). Religious aniconism (“an-icon-ism”) led to the use of this art form to render holy subjects such as the shahada, which appears on the upper half of the flag of Saudi Arabia. For 10 points, name this art form in which a brush and ink are used to render text in aesthetically appealing ways.
tossups.answer: calligraphy [prompt on handwriting, writing systems, scripts, or similar answers]
tossups.question_sanitized: Two divergent variants of this art form named “bird” and “worm” emerged in response to the introduction of bronze ware in China. Ottoman Turks developed a dense, space-filling variant of this art form known as diwani, as well as the open, expressive thuluth form. Emperor Taizong is purportedly buried with a work in this art form that was inspired by the Orchid Pavilion; that work was the magnum opus of Wang Xizhi (“SHI-cherr”). tossups.answer_sanitized: calligraphy [prompt on handwriting, writing systems, scripts, or similar answers]

tossups.question: Unit changes in this quantity perturb standard systems like silver chloride by multiples of 0.059. This quantity is measured at the surface of an instrument whose glass bulb must be kept wet at all times. The activity coefficients of assorted aniline ("an-uh-LEEN") compounds were used by Louis Hammett to introduce an alternative to this quantity. This quantity is related to an equilibrium constant with subscript “a” by a frequently-misspelled equation stated by Karl Hasselbalch (“hassle”-BALK). Red (*) cabbage juice can be used to approximate this quantity, which can also be measured using concentrate of lichen (“liken”). This logarithmic quantity spans fourteen orders of magnitude centered around the average hydrogen ion concentration of water. For 10 points, name this quantity which characterizes the strength of an acid.
tossups.answer: pH [accept pOH; prompt on concentration of hydrogen ions or protons before “logarithmic”; prompt on acidic, acidity, basic, alkaline, or similar responses with “what scale measures that?”]

tossups.answer_sanitized: pH [accept pOH; prompt on concentration of hydrogen ions or protons before “logarithmic”; prompt on acidic, acidity, basic, alkaline, or similar responses with “what scale measures that?”]

In the Qur’an, the angels Harut and Marut come down to the city of Babylon during this man’s reign. tossups.question: Stefano Laporta’s work on this particle has reduced the number of master integrals required to consider complicated Feynman- (“FINE-min)” diagrams. The five-loop QED ("Q-E-D") contribution to this particle’s anomalous magnetic moment agrees with experiment to ten significant figures, making it the most accurate prediction of any physical theory. These particles are ejected from the “core” in the Auger ("OH-zhay") effect. The mass of this particle is used to define the (*) Rydberg constant, and it has the highest probability of being detected at the Bohr radius. The LHC acts in billions of a unit equal to one volt times the charge of this lepton ("lep-TAWN"), which equals “1.6 times 10 to the negative 19th” Coulombs. For 10 points, name this point particle with negative fundamental charge that is found orbiting the nucleus of atoms.
tossups.answer: electron [accept the anomalous electron magnetic moment or electronvolt; prompt on eV (E-V)]

tossups.question: A poet with this last name wrote that "To you I offer my hull and the tattered cordage of my will" in a poem written for his lover, Larry Rivers. Another poem by an author with this last name begins with the narrator "standing in the bathtub crying," distraught at the loss of a lover and asking "Mother, Mother, who am I?" A poet with this last name mentions contemplating the purchase of Genet's (“je-NAY’s”) The Balcony before breaking down after seeing the cover of the New York Post in a poem set in 1959 three days after Bastille Day. This last name of the poet of (*) "The Day Lady Died" is also the last name of a character who has a rivalry with Melanie Hamilton and is rejected by Ashley Wilkes. For 10 points, give this last name of the American poet Frank and the Gone With the Wind heroine Scarlett.
tossups.question_sanitized: A poet with this last name wrote that "To you I offer my hull and the tattered cordage of my will" in a poem written for his lover, Larry Rivers. Another poem by an author with this last name begins with the narrator "standing in the bathtub crying," distraught at the loss of a lover and asking "Mother, Mother, who am I?" A poet with this last name mentions contemplating the purchase of Genet's (“je-NAY’s”) The Balcony before breaking down after seeing the cover of the New York Post in a poem set in 1959 three days after Bastille Day. This last name of the poet of (*) "The Day Lady Died" is also the last name of a character who has a rivalry with Melanie Hamilton and is rejected by Ashley Wilkes. For 10 points, give this last name of the American poet Frank and the Gone With the Wind heroine Scarlett.
tossups.answer_sanitized: O'Hara [accept Frank O'Hara or Scarlett O'Hara]

bonuses.leadin: In 1985, Susan Merritt proposed an “inverted taxonomy” for these algorithms that observes their “split” and “join” steps. For 10 points each:
answers: quicksort [prompt on partition-exchange sort; do not accept or prompt on “exchange sort”]
parts: Name these algorithms that place elements in a list into an order.

Under Merritt’s inverted taxonomy, the canonical hardsplit/easyjoin sorting algorithm is this one, which selects a pivot, distributes values around that pivot, and continues recursively. Under Donald Knuth’s taxonomy, this sorting algorithm is exchange-based.
Under Merritt’s taxonomy, bubble sort is a special case of quicksort with this property. Algorithms with a space complexity of 1 always have this property.

bonuses.leadin: At the 1982 World Aquatics Championships, this man had the first-ever dive to receive seven tens. For 10 points each:
answers: Quán Hóngchán [prompt on Hóngchán] (pronounced “ch’wan,” but accept pronunciations like “kwan”)
People’s Republic of China [or PRC; do not accept or prompt on “Republic of China” or “ROC”]
parts: Name this American diving legend. In the 1988 Olympics, this man sustained a concussion after hitting his head on the springboard mid-dive, and still won gold by 25 points.

In the women’s 10 metre platform event at the 2020 Olympics, this 14-year-old platform diver received seven tens on two different dives. She won the gold handily, shattering the previous scoring record with 466.20 points.
Quán (“ch’wan”) Hóngchán is an athlete from this country. This country garnered controversy for inflating its own medal count by counting the medals won by Taiwan and Hong Kong.

bonuses.leadin: The flag of the Cretan revolutionaries during the Cretan revolt was marked with four capital letters symbolizing Crete, this concept, freedom, and death. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this Greek concept meaning union. This concept was a central idea in Cyprus during the 1960s and 70s suggesting a desire for union with the mainland.

The idea of enosis in Crete was strongly promoted by Eleftherios Venizelos, who oversaw a Turkish-Greek population swap as part of this treaty signed in 1923 to supplant the treaty of Sevres (“SEV-reh”).
This author described the migrant transfer in “On the Quai ("quay") at Smyrna” while his work as an ambulance driver informed his 1929 novel A Farewell to Arms.

bonuses.leadin: When interviewing this author for Vulture, Merve Emre (“MURR-vay EM-ray”) repeatedly asked him to compare his work to George Eliot's. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this modern American novelist, who wrote The Corrections, Freedom, and Purity.
With the help of Jonathan Franzen, this other bird-loving American novelist published her first novels. This author wrote about eco-terrorism in The Wallcreeper.
For 15 years, Nell Zink only wrote fiction in this medium. A Hugo von Hoffmansthal work about writer's block pretends to be a work in this medium written by Lord Chandos.

bonuses.leadin: In the Aeneid, Virgil claimed that this god was the father of Eros. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this god. With Ares, Aphrodite cheated on this god of blacksmiths.

Vulcan, the Roman equivalent of Hephaestus, is the father of this fire-breathing giant. In Book VIII (eight) of the Aeneid, Hercules defeats this monster by gripping his throat so tightly that his eyes explode.
In one telling, Hephaestus was thrown from Mount Olympus by Hera, who was disgusted by his limp. When he landed in the ocean, he was raised by this goddess, the mother of Achilles.

bonuses.leadin: A painting by Hans Holbein depicts the features of this patron as blended with the Roman god Terminus, whom this patron had adopted as his symbol. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this patron and promoter of Holbein (“HOLE-byne”) the Younger, who also asked that his personal motto, "I concede to no one," be incorporated into portraits. This man recommended Holbein to Thomas More when Holbein moved to England.
Symbols were often incorporated into heraldic art during the middle ages. This heraldic ordinary takes the shape of two intersecting diagonal lines, such as on the flag of Scotland.

The orange tree in the back center of La Primavera is thought to be a symbol of this family that commissioned it. The red balls on the crest of this powerful Florentine family are also sometimes represented as oranges.

bonuses.leadin: Counting these things can provide an approximation of a molecule’s stability. For 10 points each:
answers: resonance structures [accept canonical structures or forms; prompt on resonance or structures]
meta position [or meta directors; accept the 3 position or 1,3]
parts: Name these things drawn with double-headed arrows between them. These things can be major contributors to a molecule’s geometry if their atoms obey the octet rule and they minimize formal charge.

Rings with this property are often drawn with a circle to represent the two ways its pi bonds can alternate. This property is the extreme of resonance which allows molecules like benzene to be much more stable.

Functional groups on an aromatic ring with electron-withdrawing resonance structures will generally direct future substitutions to this position. Halogens are the only deactivating groups which do not direct to this position.

bonuses.leadin: The selection of  “friends” available for purchase in this game was determined by the animals represented in standard emoji sets. For 10 points each:
answers: DOTA [or Defense of the Ancients; accept DOTA 2 or Defense of the Ancients 2]
parts: Identify this free auto battler game made by Team Wood. In this game, the turtle gives “melon armor” to the friend behind it upon fainting.
The auto battler genre was popularised in 2019 by the Auto Chess entry in this franchise. Valve developed the second game in this MOBA franchise, the main rival of League of Legends.

The auto battle genre began as a spinoff of a Pokemon themed game in this genre, made for multiplayer within Warcraft III. The name of this genre of strategy game is represented by the TD in the Bloons TD series, and Plants v Zombies is a popular game in this genre

bonuses.leadin: Writers in this genre can win the Edogawa Ranpo award after the author who created the character Kogoro Akechi. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this genre used by writers like Seicho Matsumoto and Seishi Yokomizo.

Natuso Kirino has written an acclaimed novel about four women at a Bento factory with this three letter English name. This word is repeated twice in the title of a Robert Frost poem about a boy losing his hand to a saw which takes its title from Macbeth.
Gosho Aoyama created Case Closed, a popular manga about a young detective with this name. Robert E. Howard created a muscular barbarian with this name who lives in the Hyborian Age.

bonuses.leadin: Hywel Dda (“HYU-well thah”) was the namesake of Wales’ law codes before the adoption of this statute. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 1284 ordinance issued by Edward I which established common law in Wales. It is named for a castle built in Denbighshire (“DIN-bick-shir”).

The Statute of Rhuddlan (“RITH-lan”) created a number of counties from Gwynedd (“gwyneth”), including Merioneth, Anglesey (“ANGLE-see”) and this county. George Herbert, Earl of this county, was the patron to Egyptologist Howard Carter.
The statute of Rhuddlan was supplanted in 1536 by this English king when the Laws in Wales act was passed. That was the same year that this king married Jane Seymour.

bonuses.leadin: Because his band was recorded in the same studio, David Arbus was asked to play the outro violin solo of this song. For 10 points each,
parts: Name this song, sometimes incorrectly called “Teenage Wasteland”.
This band, formed by Roger Daltrey and Pete Townshend, recorded the song “Baba O’Riley” in 1971.

Despite this song's similarities to “Baba O’Riley”, Pete Townshend refused legal action and instead said he appreciated that his music lived on. This song was the lead single on the 2013 album Midnight Memories.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the order of words in a sentence, for 10 points each:
answers: verb, subject, object [accept in any order; prompt on VSO in any order]
parts: Different languages have different rules for how these three things should be arranged in a sentence. These things represent the action being taken in a sentence, the thing doing the action, and the thing the action is being done to.
This is the verb-subject-object ordering in English and Mandarin.
The least common ordering, object-subject-verb, is mostly found in languages in this region. A controversial 2005 paper claimed that a language from this region lacked recursion.

bonuses.leadin: A “ladder” process named for these particles produces nickel in stars. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these particles. Elements whose most abundant isotopes are integer multiples of four are named for these particles, since their nuclei can be formed purely by the fusion of these particles.
The alpha ladder starts with this element, which is formed in the triple-alpha process. Some of the first nuclear reactors were moderated by graphite, an allotrope of this element.

The alpha ladder does not go beyond nickel due to this phenomenon becoming exothermic past iron. P-nuclei may be created by the gamma process, in which this phenomenon alters s-process and r-process nuclei.

bonuses.leadin: Magdalen-Oxford quizzer Ted Loveday mispronounced this phrase during a legendary performance on University Challenge. For 10 points each:
answers: hapax legomenon [do not accept or prompt on “hapax legonomenon”]
parts: Give this Greek-language term for a word that only occurs once in a given context, often in the entire corpus of an ancient language.

The word ealuscerwen (“AE-lus-sker-wen”) is a hapax legomenon that apparently refers to an Anglo-Saxon drinking ritual in this epic poem. This poem opens with another hapax legomenon, the interjection “hwaet!”
The word muspilli appears only once in a medieval form of this language, in a poem about the Last Judgment. “Rubble languages” considered dialects of this language include Langobardic.

bonuses.leadin: Description acceptable. This speech was the first time a Japanese emperor had ever made a speech to Japanese commoners. For 10 points each:
answers: announcement of Japanese surrender in World War II [prompt on surrender in World War II by asking, "By which country?"; prompt on Japanese surrender by asking, "In which war?"; prompt on (but DO NOT REVEAL) Hirohito speech by asking "What was the speech about?"]
parts: Identify this speech, formally called the Jewel Voice Broadcast. In it, the emperor urged the Japanese people to "endure the unendurable and suffer what is not sufferable".
This emperor gave the Jewel Voice Broadcast announcing that Japan had surrendered in World War II.

The post-World War II Japanese constitution contained this article, which renounced the national right to war and use of force in international disputes. Despite this article, Japan maintains self-defense forces that serve as a de facto military.

bonuses.leadin: This avid photographer published the 1968 photo-book Double Exposure, which included many snapshots of his fellow actors. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this actor who played Cornelius and Caesar in the original Planet of the Apes films. He also starred as TV host Peter Vincent in Tom Holland’s directorial debut, Fight Night.
Roddy McDowall took the photograph used for the cover of The Third Album by this singer. This star of Funny Girl won an Oscar for composing the theme of the 1976 version of A Star is Born.

This actor is likely McDowall’s chief rival for most successful actor-photographer. Ed Ruscha based a painting off Double Standard, a photo of a gas station that this actor took from the driver’s seat of his car.

bonuses.leadin: In 1800, this man was tasked by Napoleon with developing a submarine; that 1800 raft was called the Nautilus. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this American engineer who developed the world’s first steamboat known as the North River Steamboat.
After switching allegiances, Fulton worked for the British government developing early torpedoes, but found he was less in demand as a result of this 1805 victory for Horatio Nelson.
Fulton’s North River Steamboat carried passengers to this city, named for the Scottish Duchy of James II and VII (seventh). Martin Van Buren led a political machine described as this city’s Regency.

bonuses.leadin: Elena MacGregor designed one of these memorials which was used controversially as the central part of the logo for the 2010 Winter Olympics. For 10 points:
parts: Name these stone cairns left as landmarks or navigation points by Inuit peoples.
An inuksuk is used on the flag of this Canadian territory, whose capital of Iqaluit (“ee-CALL-you-it”) is home to Inuksuk High School.
Over 1000 inuksuit were placed on the Chedoke (“che-DOKE”) Radial Trail to memorialize missing and murdered indigenous women near Hamilton in this Canadian province across from Niagara Falls.

bonuses.leadin: Identify some musical representations of the apocalypse, for 10 points each:
answers: the Ring Cycle [or The Ring of the Nibelung or Nibelungenlied]
parts: The final section of this operatic cycle, Götterdämmerung, is a literal German rendering of the Norse concept of Ragnarök.
While held by the Nazis as a prisoner of war, this composer produced his Quartet for the End of Time, which opens with a blackbird-inspired “Crystal Liturgy”.

This composer intended for his piece Mysterium to be performed in the foothills of the Himalayas, and for the week-long event to be followed by the apocalypse and replacement of humanity with a more noble species.

bonuses.leadin: This phrase is referred to as "the Old Lie" in a poem originally planned to be dedicated to Jessie Pope. For 10 points each:
answers: "dulce et decorum est pro patria mori" [accept it is sweet and right to die for one's country or similar English translations; prompt on dulce et decorum est or it is sweet and right by asking, "What is the rest of the line?"]
parts: Give this poetic phrase. This phrase is preceded by a line about "plunging through a tide of blood" in its original poem, a line echoed by a man who is "plunging...choking, drowning" in another poem titled for this phrase.
The phrase "dulce et decorum est pro patria mori" comes from a poem of this type written by Horace. In general, these poems celebrate a person, thing, or idea, such as melancholy, or the West Wind.
This poet celebrated winners of athletic games in his epinician (“epi-NICK-ian”) odes, such as Olympian 1, which celebrates the victory of Hieron (“HERE-on”) of Sicily.
